transport.comment:
Look. I don't know why everyone is getting so defensive about this. I originally told him to buy the panel, but since he doesn't have the capital currently I mentioned considering a lease as an alternative and now I've gotten several rude responses and PMs which I don't feel like I deserve.

Is owning a system better in the long run? Usually yes.

But it becomes less clear if you are taking out a loan to pay for solar. are you going to stay in the same house for 25+ years to see the benefit? Owning doesn't pay back for like 10 years or so... Do you owe taxes typically or get a refund? Do you want the extra liability of owning the system? Can you sell back to the grid? How many incentives, rebates, and tax credits do you qualify for? What is your cost of electricity? *CAN YOU AFFORD TO BUY THE FUCKING SOLAR PANELS IN THE FIRST PLACE?*

Lessing still saves money compared to paying utilities, but owning can save maybe 50% more in the long run.

transport.comment:
For sure, obviously if you have the cash on hand to spend on the panels then you're going to get far and away the best return. 

I could easily qualify for a loan, my credit is more than good enough to do so. The issue is most solar loans I've come across are somewhere in the 4-5% interest range. Even taking into account all the tax credits and the SREC's that come along with owning your own panels. That interest rate is MASSIVE. And honestly kills a lot of your return value. Odds are the loan isn't paid off for 8-10 years. At that point you've probably accumulated several thousand in interest and if you want to go sell the house now, you'll 'maybe' break even with the increase in home value. 

Right now this is our "starter" home so to speak. We really only intend on being here for 10-12 years tops as long as things don't go horribly wrong in our lives over the next decade. So I think in our future home, I'll probably look into buying panels out right with cash on hand. 

But for the time being I think leasing is the best way to save a chunk of money over the short and long term. And also make the house more appealing for resale. Initially I thought the lease might be a detriment to resale but the more I think about the more I'm changing my thought process there. 

That thought process started because my father HATES solar panels and thinks they're awful. That said, most people under 30 have a wildly different opinion than that. In the next 8-10 years as solar becomes more and more normal in our everyday lives it won't be seen as a detriment. It could be to the point where people specifically look for homes that already have solar capability. Especially first time homebuyers who won't have the money to buy the panels themselves. It'll be a different generation, taking my 58 year old fathers opinion into account is kind of silly in retrospect. I'm not going to be selling my house to a 55-60 year old more than likely.

transport.comment:
When I bought my EV I was going to get a used Leaf,, 2015 or 2014 model. I decided against it due to a poor rating on one of the IIHS safety tests - http://www.iihs.org/iihs/ratings/vehicle/v/nissan/leaf-4-door-hatchback

I ended up purchasing a new 2016 Chevy Spark EV, with the tax credit it came out to a little over what I'd have paid for the used Leaf.

The biggest trade off has been fast charging, and I knew this when I made my decision, which is why it was a tough one. The Leaf uses CHADeMo which has a great network, especially where I live on the West Coast of the US. The Spark EV uses CCS which is pretty limited. Given that I rarely go on road trips, I decided to keep my Zipcar membership in case I needed a car for something like that, I can always rent a Hybrid.

For insurance, it depends on what coverage you get. If you're getting a new care and financing, then you will have to carry more insurance. I used an unsecured loan but opted for higher coverage. EV's will typically cost more. 6 months of a crap ton of coverage costs me $500 through State Farm. If you don't drive a lot you can get mileage based coverage, you have to install a device in your car. I opted not to go that route because privacy but it would have saved a lot of money. 

As far as maintenance goes, electric cars need very little since they don't use that crazy gas engine.

Good luck on your Leaf purchase! EV's are awesome, whichever car you choose!

PARIS -- Peugeot said it will offer a full-electric version of the 308 compact hatchback by 2023, a previously unannounced powertrain configuration that could compete with the Volkswagen ID3.

The new-generation Astra from sister brand Opel/Vauxhall will also have a full-electric version, according to news reports. 

The new 308 was introduced earlier this month, with sales set to start in the second half, but only with internal combustion and plug-in hybrid options.

A Peugeot spokesman confirmed Wednesday that a full-electric version has been approved for production in 2023, but said it was "too early" to offer any more details, including what platform it would be built on.

The technical details of a full-electric 308 are not yet clear, although there are two options within parent company Stellantis. The group's newest compact EV, the Citroen C4, is built on the CMP architecture for small and compact cars, which can accommodate gasoline, diesel or full-electric drivetrains. But the 308 is built on the EMP2 platform, which is for compact and midsize models and is designed for plug-in hybrid electrification, not full electric.

A more likely choice is the coming e-VMP architecture, a battery-electric adaptation of EMP2 that will first appear on the next generation of Peugeot 3008 compact SUVs, slated for launch by 2023.

Stellantis is in the process of vertically integrating its electrified drivetrains, with a collaboration with Nidec on electric motors, with Punch Powertrain on transmissions and with Total/Saft on battery cell factories.

The 3008 is scheduled to be built at Stellantis' factory in Sochaux, eastern France. The 308 will be built at the group's nearby Mulhouse factory.

###Astra plug-in hybrid

The new Astra is scheduled to be launched later this year, with production set for Opel's home factory in Ruesselsheim, Germany, where it will be built alongside the DS 4 compact car also based on PSA's EMP2 platform.

Reuters reported on Wednesday that a full-electric Astra would appear this year, without providing any more details.

The Astra will have a plug-in hybrid variant, Opel CEO Michael Lohscheller told German motoring magazine auto-motor-sport in an interview.

An Opel spokesman told Automotive News Europe that while the new Astra will have a hybrid option, a full-electric option would not be offered this year. The spokesman said Opel would not comment further on future product plans for competitive reasons.

Vauxhall-branded Astras have been built in Ellesmere Port, England, but Brexit has left the factory's future role in doubt. Opel said in 2019 that the next Astra would be built in two European factories. The company has not yet disclosed the Astra's second production location in addition to Ruesselsheim.

###Segment starts to electrify

The news about the full-electric 308 was first reported in French news media. In a video segment recorded by the enthusiast magazine Auto-Moto and broadcast last week, Agnes Tesson-Faget, the product executive for the new 308, said a full-electric 308 was in the works.

Another French media outlet, L'Argus, said Monday that Peugeot brand CEO Linda Jackson had confirmed in an interview that an electric 308 was coming in 2023. 

The compact segment, the third-largest in Europe in 2020, is starting to see more full-electric options. The Nissan Leaf had long been the only EV available, but the ID3, launched last autumn, has recorded 6,858 sales through February, according to data from JATO Dynamics, about one-third of the segment-leading VW Golf. Nissan has sold 3,514 Leafs through February.

In addition to the full-electric Citroen C4, the Renault Megane-e is slated to appear in 2022, and the Cupra Born, a higher-performance version of the ID3 from the Seat performance subbrand on the same VW Group MEB platform, will go into production toward the end of this year.

Potential, although unannounced, vehicles could include a Skoda version of the ID3 and a Ford vehicle on Volkswagen's MEB platform under a technology sharing agreement.

transport.comment:
I lose about 40% range in the winter, I'm a little colder than you. The battery will not last more than about 15 years, figure about 25% degradation in that time. You also don't want to use more than about 80% of the battery in a day to prevent rapid degradation. So you put all that together:

250 mi EPA range x 60% winter range x 75% health after 15 years x 80% per day = 90 miles worst case range.

My commute is only 60 miles per day, so I'll be good until the battery needs to be replaced in 10-15 years.

Automakers are required by federal law to supply parts for a minimum of 10 years. And the Model 3 is popular so I'd expect parts to be available or harvested from junkyards for quite a bit longer than that.

transport.comment:
It's a good question that I don't know the answer to... I think J2954 is optimized for 10 inches of vertical separation... So I think efficiency will fall off if the vehicle is sitting on top of too much snow, but I think it would take several inches ( packed under the tires ) to make a really big difference... https://www.researchgate.net/publication/357919998_Effect_of_Additional_Transmitting_Coils_on_Transfer_Distance_in_Multiple-Transmitter_Wireless_Power_Transfer_System

As for whether the presence of snow would directly affect the efficiency, it's a magnetic field...I don't think the presence of snow between the plates would affect the efficiency... but I'm willing to be told otherwise...

>No problem until theyre completely buried and the longer cable gives you flexibility to park around snow drifts.

My concerns, as someone who plowed snow many years ago, is that pedestals will make the process of plowing a lot more difficult once you have enough electric cars that you need pedestals installed in the middle of the lot, ie once you've used up all the peripheral spaces.

Also, at least around here ( Boston ) the cables tend to be draped on the ground which increases the chance of cutting cables with the plow. Chargers along the side of the road are begging for their cables to get cut. ( We could go to cables that hang down, like I think some of the EA chargers do... But I don't think you want 7 foot tall EVSEs along every sidewalk ).

Finally, cables in general are going to get frozen to the ground in snow + ice storms... And thoughtless people will just drop charging handles into the snow / ice...

Let's not even get into the subject of how many will be taken out by drivers who don't see them in their blind spots... Again, probably not an issue while the chargers can be made to fit the periphery of the lot... But if they're in the middle of the lot...

Even ignoring snow & ice, physical connectors have lots of issues... There was a reddit post a while back where the screwed up charger port wrecked a pin on the car... That could strand you if you can no longer charge...

It's certainly going to be interesting to watch this all unfold!!!

housing.comment:
I think it would be physically possible with current technology, but it definitely would not be worth the expense. 

Let's take Hawaii, for example.  Hawaii has the most expensive electricity of any state in the United States.  It also gets a lot of sun and naturally has the highest solar per capita.   Land in Hawaii is also very expensive and since it is made up of a bunch of islands, most places are close to the ocean.  If any place is ideal for floating solar panels, Hawaii would seem to be it.

Problem 1: Building anything on the ocean is darn near impossible in Hawaii. Impossible.  The environmentalists freak out over anything built on or near the ocean.  A while back, there was a plan to install floating ocean windmills, far enough off the coast, so they could not be seen.  This plan was curb stomped so fast the developer probably didn't even spend more than $5,000 pushing the idea.  From a political or permitting standpoint, a large solar array on the ocean cannot be built. 

Problem 2: Installing panels on roofs is MUCH cheaper and a very developed technology.  Despite the tons of solar penetration, there are tons of empty roofs in Hawaii.  Land, or rather space for solar panels, isn't sparse enough to warrant building stuff on the ocean.

Problem 3: Storms.  I can't imagine how much insurance would be for a solar farm.  This is the [2015 hurricane season for Hawaii in one image.](http://wxshift.com/uploads/img-news/11_19_15_Brian_WXThumb_HawaiiHurricane.jpg) Yeah, that's a lot of storms.

housing.comment:
That's going to depend on the customer's system and usage patterns (and utility), of course. But today, most customers should benefit significantly, particularly if they have west facing panels, because most of their generation is during peak/semi peak hours, but much of their consumption is during off peak hours (or during winter with lower peak pricing). There's only really a risk of being a net loss if your solar array production doesn't come anywhere close to matching your consumption (and even then, it could still be a net win if you can shift enough of your consumption out of peak hours).

There are really two major implications of TOU:

1.  It penalizes east facing panels and rewards west facing panels (the major CA utilities have TOU peak hours in the range of noon to 7pm). I'm not going to do the math, but west facing panels may give better returns than south facing.
2. In the future, as solar adoption increases, peak hours will shift. Solar noon will become off peak instead high demand, and solar customers will find that with typical usage patterns, much of their production stops being credited at peak rates while much of their consumption is still billed at peak rates (unless they make an effort to shift load out of peak times). In 2020, TOU net metering could be a much worse deal than flat rate net metering.

housing.comment:
So the missing link is that they're giving you efficiency at the plate and not mentioning the space required for the lensing.

A usual panel is 5'x3' or so that generates at 18% efficiency or so but across it's entire surface.  A CSP concentrates light and so has a 50%+ potential but do not generate across a 5'x3' surface, the PV plate in this case is usually small.  So while yes, at the plate it is quite efficient, the lensing required for each plate takes up more space than the less efficient regular ol' PV panel without the needed lens.

This all without mentioning tracking, which can be built-in to the lens now but definitely needs some extra maintenance.

housing.comment:
>That's an unreasonable position. What you should pay in 5 years is a somewhat-discounted (for 5 years of wear-and-tear) rate based not in any sense on whatever the original cost is but on the cost of a comparable system (given rebates available) at the time you buy the house.

Who said home buyers are reasonable?  

If you spend $50,000 on a pool, do you think you'll get $50,000 back when you sell your house a few year later because that's what it would cost to replace the pool?  Of course not. You'll be lucky to get $20,000 of it back.

You can expect whatever you want, but reality is buyers aren't going to pay you full depreciated value for your solar panels.  They are going to compare your house to the one down the street and think "Well, wolftune's house has solar, so I guess it's worth a little bit more, but I really like the kitchen layout in the other house, so lets buy the one with the nicer kitchen."  That's the level of analysis you need to expect.

Also, maybe your solar system is ideally sized for your usage, but maybe not for a buyer.  Therefore it won't have the same value to them as it does for you.

Don't get me wrong, I've got solar panels myself that I spent $25,000 on.  I would love to get most of that back when I sell my house, but I'm not counting on it, especially when that is only 2-3% of the overall value of my house and would be impossible to quantify one way or the other.

housing.comment:
That's a complicated question. Yes, the economics of solar have been getting drastically more competitive (for certain applications) compared to conventional fossil fuel energy sources. The future of the industry should therefore be bright. :) However, you need to remember several things about solar:

1. Energy is a highly regulated industry globally.  Along with that solar is highly dependent on federal and state incentive programs (in the US at least).  Political and regulatory changes are a big reason for the industry moniker - "The Solar Coaster". See latest tariffs on steel and modules for a recent example.
2. Office job salaries are going to depend highly on the type of firm, and where that company sits in the market. SolarEdge employees, for example, will be printing money due to their patented technology they have been able to bake into building code regulations. Some poor schmuck at a mom & pop residential installer company with no unique value proposition could struggle to do well in a race to the bottom cost.
3. There has been a ton of hype around solar, and photovoltaics specifically, for the past 10-15 years, and so I'd argue that salaries are driven down compared to other industries by the "ideologists" taking pay cuts for the opportunity to work in Solar. Yes, the industry is competitive.
4. Big technical solutions are needed to overcome a key limitation to solar - our stupid sun plays peekaboo for 12 hours a day. How am I supposed to microwave popcorn at night when its dark?!? Solutions are in the works:

a) Add battery storage to the grid

b) Make the grid more efficient at dealing with variable energy generation and demand, and

c) Stop the earth from spinning!!

Until those solutions are here, the grid has a limit as to how much solar it can accept and so the solar industry has a cap. We ain't close to that cap in the US yet, FYI.

&#x200B;

To get specific about salaries, find your desired role on the IREC career map:

[http://www.irecsolarcareermap.org/](http://www.irecsolarcareermap.org/)

And then search salaries for that job title on your favorite job board. Also, check out the career pages of companies that attend solar conferences like SPI, ASES, etc.

&#x200B;

A couple general suggestions for you:

1. Look into Quality/Lean/Six Sigma methods so you can bring continuous improvement to wherever you end up. Noone in solar will care if you actually have those certs, but every job you ever have will value your ability to effectively solve problems, and most importantly prevent the problems from ever happening again.
2. Learn how to automate/script things. You don't have to be a coding prodigy, but just being able to make excel formulas will take you a long way. Every solar project will be similar, so get a computer to do the repetitive things!

&#x200B;

Best of luck to you, and don't believe a thing I said because I don't know what I'm talking about.

housing.comment:
Greetings everyone, new here, TIA for help and for being gentle with me as I learn my way through circuits and power.

After two small, but scary fires with an LP fridge at our fly-in cabin, we replaced one of our LP fridges with a Unique [370L1](https://uniqueappliances.com/product/unique-13-0-cu-ft-solar-powered-dc-fridge/) Solar/DC fridge.. We have been very happy so far, and are looking to replace the other LP fridge with a Unique [470](https://uniqueappliances.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/UGP-470L_solar_fridge_manual_Eng_V5_2017.pdf), and I am looking for advice on best approach on the combined solar system..

Our fridge setup is currently separate from our main solar electrical - it might makes sense to combine them eventually, but that is a post for another time.

I believe our current fridge solar setup consists of:

* two 270 watt/24v solar panels  

   * 570w \* 6 hours of good sun a day (which is conservative in northern Ontario summers, many days are 10+) \* .75 buffer = 2,565 wh/day charge capacity. (106 ah @ 24v).
* Armada [ARC40-MPPT](https://static1.squarespace.com/static/57ec05e5bebafbd7890d75e0/t/5dd2d7e958983f13f1b7ddf7/1574098923358/ARC20%2C30%2C40-MPPT+Data+Sheet.pdf) controller,
* four 205Ah 6v batteries in series to get to 24v out  

   * 100Ah 'safe' capacity to keep the batteries from discharging beyond 50%. (?? I am pretty sure the dealer said 10 days, but that seems as though it would be at full drain? and the controller would cut off before then to prevent battery drain?)

Here are the power specs of the two fridges.

**370 470 combined**

12/24V 24V (system will be at 24V).

2.6 amp 6.2A 8.2A

62W 148W 210 W

24Ah/day. 28Ah/day 52 ah/day

587 Wh/day 865Wh/day 1400 wh/day

The ARC40 can handle a 20A load current, so we should be fine there.

If I added an addition 220ah (this time in parallel) - and my calculations are correct (big 'if'), we should stay at around 4 days of battery only power.

Add \~300 more watts of solar power (controller can handle 1100W on 24V), that would give us 840w total charge capacity. 840\*6\*.75 = 3780 wh/day, or 157 ah, which would be enough to power the system and recharge half the battery bank on a conservative day.

Am i missing anything that would prevent the fridges from running in series on the proposed system?

If there are any experts out there that like remote walleye/northern/lake trout fishing, I might entertain a trade of goods/services for cabin use :).

Thanks again for any help. If this is better suited for another sub, let me know. (Or should I cross post?)

housing.comment:
1) Reduce, Reuse, Recycle... In that order. Just because you can afford it doesn't mean it's worth it and you should. Consumerism and marketing will attempt to trick you at every corner! Do you really need that stuff? 

2) Switch your power company over to a renewable energy option if available. If you don't live in an area that provides renewable energy options from the distributor then consider installing solar panels or if you just like the idea and have good sunlight access.

3) Reduce redundant and unnecessary transportation and plan to buy an electric car even if it cost a little bit more. There is significant savings per year in gas and affordable options will be here very soon and gas will probably be going up as the planet finally decides to start doing something about climate change. The next batch of affordable electric cars should be in the 20 to $30,000 range making them only a little bit more expensive for a vehicle that probably depreciates much slower. 

4) Seal up your houses air leaks and transition to heat pumps for all your heating needs. Upgrade the programmable thermostats if you haven't. Do a better job at sealing window air conditioners or upgrade to ductless mini split heat pumps. Open the windows and use ventilation when temperature and humidity allow. Reduce your heating and cooling load by sealing off sections of your house and only air conditioning the places you need as well as wearing more clothes around the house in the winter and using electric blankets. 

5) Transition your diet to low CO2 and low water use per calorie foods.

6) Choose homes and rentals that are more energy efficient and have the minimal amount of climate excess climate controlled area. If you can add porches and sheds and other non-climate controlled areas that is far more ideal than taking on a bunch of square feet you don't really need to heat and cool. 

7) Upgrade all your lighting to LED, its significantly more efficient. 

8) Avoid high wattage resistance heating like plug-in heaters or using your coffee pot as a heating pad. It's more efficient to heat things up in the microwave. It makes sense for electric blankets because you minimize the distribution loss by being in physical contact with the thing getting warm so the wattage required is low and you can keep the entire house cooler. Somebody needs to invent a cooling blanket to go along with our heating blankets and we could probably all turn our thermostats down significantly.

9) Reduce your hot water usage and try to avoid unnecessarily burning through lots of different outfits per day and creating a bunch of laundry, but also don't do tiny loads of laundry because that's not nearly as energy efficient. The new hybrid water heaters will probably be the way to go though they're still a little bit new for now.

10) Research your energy bill and try to get it as low as possible. Some people don't realize the devices in their home that may be using the most wattage, like maybe a dehumidifier that runs all the time. It might not seem like it's doing much, but they are not very energy efficient. Plug-in heaters are also not efficient, though they could be reasonably used to heat one room in your house while keeping the rest of the house at a significantly lower temperature. Those old school high intensity discharge lights like people put up on polls or on their garages are also particularly inefficient especially when you leave them out there for years and they've lost huge amounts of their output but still burn up tons of wattage. Understanding what in your home uses the most wattage is a good plan in general.

housing.comment:
We got a PwrCell system installed in June. 13.5KW solar + 17.1KWhr battery pack (this is before the recent capacity upgrades).

One thing I REALLY like about this system vs PowerWall is the batteries are on the same DC bus as the solar panels. That means during peak solar output in the summer, when the panels are putting out more than the 8.1ish KW the inverter consume the extra can get pushed into the battery pack. In the summer we kept the pack with a min reserve around 35% and on really sunny days it would charge up to around 95% then drain back to the grid when the panel production went down in the evening. Ended up increasing our net-meter output by several KWh each day.

My biggest gripe is they still don't have a way to control it remotely. Ideally I'd be able to set mode, min reserve, and max reserve remotely. Right now that is only doable via the control panel on the inverter which is annoying.

Let me know if you have other questions about it.

housing.comment:
# You're not just paying for the car itself. That has NEVER been the case even since the Model T. The price partly reflects Rivian's efforts to bring a brand new BEV to the USDM and establish itself as a BEV manufacturer.

The past, present, and future of the product dictates the price you'll pay. It's not just the actual product you own but the services you use, the future software updates that can be pushed, the hardware that has to be installed with future software updates in mind, the logistics of delivering and marketing a vehicle let alone a brand new company (a car company at that too). You're paying a portion of their legal defense and insurance when something breaks with the product and then someone gets hurt or something gets damaged. A product is never just limited to what you can hold, own, and use. It's not that simple.

The United States is 50 states. 50 different areas where laws have to be interpreted and prepared for not only when launching a car model but also an actual company itself with that car model. Just like how Tesla had to get through all the red tape before selling the Model S. State AND federal regulations have to be obeyed like tint level, license plate locations, etc. 50 different areas where weather and animals have to be accounted for (see Mazda's engine and spider problem, Denver's problem with rabbits nibbling car wires, etc.).

You're correct. It's no longer a complicated engine with many moving parts. It's complicated battery chemistry, complicated battery storage and temperature maintenance, complicated battery health monitors with sensors, federal crash test requirements, passive and active safety systems, first responder considerations, electrical safety regulations when the vehicle is operated by someone who obviously isn't an electrician or engineer or is being charged at a less than stellar charging station.

If the car ends up in an accident and a fire starts, that's a completely different story for an ICE car vs. a BEV.

If this was Europe or China, that would be an entirely different story with a different price tag. That's one of the literal prices we pay for being able to drive and operate motorized vehicles (and now BEV's) in our country.

housing.comment:
Well guys, using my alt account to avoid someone finding me out, but I worked at POWERHOME for about 6 months selling, and this company is robbing you blind.

The interest rates are only 2.99-4.49% but they overcharge by a mile. In training we were told we're selling "the mercedes of solar panels" which meant we were charging 5.50-8.00 per watt for Silfab panels and Generac batteries.(nothing special about them) 

We charged customers $20,000 for a Generac PWRcell 8.7Kwh base model. Other companies were installing them for 11-13,000.

It was regular for me to show someone a 90,000 quote that had a large electric bill. Basically they charged as high as they could while still "saving you money over 30 years" .

Their Energy Efficiency Package is where is gets really sketchy. Basically they have roof insulation, led light bulbs, sink faucets, etc that they're claiming will cut your energy usage by 20+%.

Problem is, basically every house already has those things, or at the very least has a good portion. This means we'd build up a system for a "90-95%" offset and by the time you take that bullshit off the quote it'd be down to 70% actual solar offset. Most salesman barely went over this. 

The final part, talking on that douche nozzle Waller "get rich like me". The salesman are HEAVILY incentivized to close in the house. Basically they're preying on people who know nothing about solar, and pushing them to close in the house before they can shop around. The salesman are paid 5% of the revenue on those company appointments and 10% on self generated ...... most don't give a shit if it's right for you because they're making 2-10 grand to get you to close. Nothing illegal there, it's a tough  job, but it's highly unethical. The appointments were dwindling when I quit so I'm hoping this is the beginning of their fall.

WHATEVER YOU DO, DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM THIS COMPANY!!!!!!!

Disclaimer. Most of the salesman aren't to blame. They purposely hire people with no sales/ business experience, and the top performing salesmen were clearly not the people who looked into pricing or even began to question our sales tactics. It's the company's fault for misleading them.

housing.comment:
I feel the same way as you're comments about how 'renewables and solar have reached a cult like level of support' except about Nuclear's supporters.

Nobody said solar is the only option. You just pretended that's what was said then go on to make an argument against it. (I can't remember what that tactic is called at the moment.)

Also, that Quora post you linked about 200 million solar panels is based off an extremely conservative estimate using the low bounds on the solar side. It's also based in Connecticut, which has a lower solar Irradiance then Tennessee. ( Also, you say it's 13 sq miles, it's not  it's 169. A 13 x 13 square.) Using the same formulas as that random poster on Quora I came up with a 6x6 square. What do you get when you do it?

Even better is that we don't have to do 'back of the napkin' math. The worlds largest Solar Farm is 22 square miles (\~5x5) and produces 2.2GW's. So, that's a pretty good estimate of how many square miles it would take to equal a Nuclear plant (depending on the nuclear plant size, of course.)

I can't help but feel there's a astro-turf campaign to keep Nuclear's opinion positive on public forums like this one. Either that, or people are re-using the same arguments with the same data from 10-15 years ago.

Bleh, but really, it doesn't matter. Technology doesn't care about arguments, if solar is working, then it's working, whether you think it still immature or not. The sad part is public policy is shaped by public opinion (or industry opinion, if we're being honest) and if those opinions are that renewables can't do it alone and need nuclear, then they're going to build nuclear. (Which is why astro-turfing could be effective.)

Luckily, there's strong support of skipping the 'tie-over-tech' and just implementing sustainable solutions now, which is kind of what we need, right?

Bah,  if only we could all just be 'sensible', right?

housing.comment:
I have the same brand of charge controller.  PV is photovoltaic, aka your solar panels.  It's showing how much is coming from the panels.  You can cycle through the menu to show PV volts and amps.  Multiply that number and you get watts.

Batt is battery obviously.  It's showing how much current is feeding into the battery.  Once again, multiply the numbers to get watts.  What's important to know is the PV numbers won't always be the same as the batt number.  The charge controller is responsible for regulating how much to send to the battery.  If it's a sunny day, but your battery is at 100%, then the charge controller stops charging the battery.

Load is if you have something directly connected to the charge controller.  It will show how much you're drawing.  The only thing I have directly to my charge controller are some 12volt lights.  You should have only 2 buttons on the charge controller if it's like mine.  The left one cycles through the menu, the right one turns on/off the device connected to the load.  So that's how I turn on/off my lights.

I guess people never see the compromises in what they have already. In my ICE days I found myself driving a Mercedes S class for a week ( my daily is a Mazda). But that week taught me all about the joys of cruising silently in utter comfort and every convenience possible. Lets assume that German luxo-barge only had a modest EV range. If youd asked me if Id swap my Mazda to keep that driving experience but with less range and need to take extra time on long drives Id have traded in an instant, even though Id never consciously wanted any of the luxuries. 

Now were effortlessly cruising around in our Volvo c40, driving from home-grown electricity from our solar panels having ditched the rattles and noise of our diesel car. Its not the fact that other cars have better range or speed - this experience just feels good in a way itd be hard to describe without trying it.

housing.comment:
First, it depends which utility both of you are on.  It would help if you told us that.  If you guys are both CPUC utilities, then his guy doesn't know what he's talking about.  However, if he's on SMUD or LADWP or municipal utility, then his guy is right, but you're also then not comparing apples to apples if you're on a CPUC utility.

Basically on 3.0, if you go without a battery, you're basically going to be giving the utility lots of free energy because the net metering agreement is so bad.  It's shifted the cost to the consumer (you) to get batteries.  You'd need to capture all that excess energy you're producing during the day that you can use right away by the batteries, so it's just going to be lost and you'll have to pay to pull it back from the grid some other time.

Buying is always better.  Finance if you have to.  I would not lease if you can help it.  You don't get the 30% credit because you don't own the panels.  And you'd have to get the solar company's permission to do any work on your own roof!  Plus they are going to be taking a lot more of the savings of solar through their lease.

food.comment:
The athletes on the carb supplement got 1.36g/kg bodyweight, this is more than 0.8g/kg body weight you cited, and substantially more than 0.3g/kg body weight you cited earlier. 

If you actually read the other scientific journals (and don't misinterpret them) you will see that higher protein consumption is conducive to retaining muscle mass while in a caloric deficit and trying to reduce body fat. Also maybe read up on net nitrogen balance, in that study (which was carried out for a month), they found 1.4-1.5g/kg to be optimal for newbie lifters and gain in muscle mass. No distinction was made for fat loss (where a higher net protein consumption would be better). They've repeatedly demonstrate that though, as well as showing during periods of weight loss more protein is better. Also there's not exactly many real world examples of vegan athletes at the top tiers of fitness. In fact I'd venture to say there is a *much* smaller proportion of vegan athletes in the top tier of fitness when compared to the average population and the number of vegans:non-vegans.

**TL;DR**: I know plenty of people who are either fast, strong, or both, and plenty of people with six packs or a great deal of muscular definition; but none of them are vegans. I know a few vegans and they're mostly pudgy balls of dough.

I would say find out where you're going, research the place, and then call and put your order in and what time you'll be arriving. Then when you get there just let the waitress know. If the person you're with asks why you ordered earlier, say that you're vegan and it was just easier. 

I don't think this makes you look bad or pretentious at all. I haven't had to personally do this yet, but I can only imagine that I will run into this problem sooner or later. This is just what I would do.

I also wouldn't lie to anyone you work with, pretending that you have food allergies or something, because they'll probably end up finding out anyway. In my opinion it just makes you look weak and unsure of yourself. Try to be yourself, and as casual as possible about it.

food.comment: Agreed. Sounds similar to my situation, too. My last 2 dogs were rescues, and I just figured I would let them hang out with me and I'll pamper them and we'll have fun together, instead of being killed. After they passed, up until I was vegan, I really wanted to get another dog. The companionship is awesome. But since going vegan, I can't impose my will on them like that. Who knows, maybe my rescues would have preferred being killed than have to live in my house, eat dog food, be neutered, be on a leash all the time, etc. Not saying they would prefer death to living with a human, but I don't know that they wouldn't, either, and I think that's the main problem. We have to impose our will on them and make that decision for them, and that's not cool. Kind of in the same vein that my friends who own chickens have decided it's OK to take their eggs because they give them a yard and food and stuff to live. Who's to say the chickens want that or think that's fair? My friends have made that decision for them, and I don't think that's right.

food.comment:
You could get enough protein without supplements. And even if you need protein powder that's still cheap per portion (20-30p for 20g of protein). Meat is more expensive than that per gram of protein. 

B12 is like 5 a year, or less. 

Creatine is a non-essential amino acid, but if you decide you do want it you can get enough for a year for 10-15. 

How is that expensive? 15-20 a year plus protein powder (if you want it) which is cheaper per portion than meat.

A vegan athlete definitely does not need to take protein supplements. They can but they don't need to.

food.comment:
I believe the way most people that are the most familiar with the difference between all these terms mostly use vegan for ethics, plant-based for a solely plant based diet (unrelated to animals rights or maybe even somewhat connected, in their own way, but focus is solely on diet). 
Ive also heard people use "mostly plant-based" to mean that a large amount of their diet is plant based but its not exclusive.

Then theres vegetarian, pescatarian, etc. 

Beyond that I believe that although vegans that turn no-vegan do obviously exist, most people that do were plant-based to begin with. Even sometimes without being aware of it. I have spoken with many people claiming to be vegan when their only consideration was diet. Which was (if Im not mistaken) one of the reasons why vegans began to make the distinction between vegan and plant-based. 

Because if youre plant-based because you dont agree with the industry (not necessarily that eating animals is wrong) or for health or the environment, you can kinda break those rules occasionally or even disregard them eventually.

food.comment:
I totally understand the struggle with trying to maintain a vegan diet while avoiding certain ingredients and also catering to specific health needs. It's challenging but not impossible!

First off, kudos to you for being attentive to your health and diet. You might want to consider legume-based protein sources such as lentils, chickpeas, and beans. They can be versatile in recipes and provide a good amount of protein. Additionally, explore protein-packed seeds like chia, flaxseed, and hemp. These can be easily integrated into smoothies, oatmeal, or baked goods.

Another option is to find plant-based protein powders that are free from seed oils and gluten. Pea protein, for example, can be a good fit for your dietary requirements. 

If you do decide to reintroduce animal-based protein, it's essential to do what feels right for your body and health. Listen to your body, and prioritize your well-being. 

Lastly, perhaps you could reach out to vegan communities or forums online. Many people might have had similar experiences and can offer recipes, alternatives, or suggestions to help you on your journey. Stay strong and best of luck!

food.comment: I havent cooked anything outside of a microwave in years. There are plenty of vegan microwaveable options like canned chilli, pre-packaged asian foods (I eat a lot of pad thai and teriyaki bowls), frozen meals like burritos, pastas, and mock meats, and you can make high calorie smoothies too with peanut butter, tofu, frozen fruits and vegetables. Cereal with your choice of plant based milk is easy, along with oatmeal and granola bars. Nearly everything I buy is recycleable and it isnt very expensive (although not as cheap as whole foods.) As long as you buy a variety of these foods and are making smoothies you can easily hit your nutrient goals. I take a multivitamin too though because why not. Been going like this for several years and I feel perfect health wise.

food.comment: Find their pain point. What are they struggling with? Show them how vegan can help solve their issue. It could be weight-how could granny make that cream pie healthier? It could be spending too much on groceries. Show them how much they can save with vegan. This is basic sales/marketing. Find out what they need first. Then offer the vegan solution. It doesnt always work. I used to talk to 100s/day abt solar. If I was lucky I would make 1 sale. But over 10 yrs I have helped save so much carbon, mostly to ppl who didnt care abt climate like I did but they did want to save $$. Can you go to stores & demo vegan food? Then youll see. You can effect change if you marry your passion to purposeful action.
